title: Episode 46 – Xiye Bastida, Global Youth Leader: “Strike with Us!”
subtitle: Sarah Arao Mantle of Hope- Thank You Video to the Y on Earth Community for GoFundMe Campaign Support
full_transcript:
[6.8s - 12.0s]: Welcome to the Y on Earth community's Stewardship and Sustainability Podcast series.

[12.9s - 16.9s]: Today we have the opportunity to visit with Shia Bastida.

[17.4s - 17.8s]: Hey Shia.

[18.0s - 18.3s]: Hi.

[18.6s - 19.2s]: How are you doing today?

[19.5s - 19.8s]: I'm good.

[20.3s - 20.6s]: Great.

[20.9s - 24.9s]: So excited to have this conversation with you and to share with our audience all of the

[24.9s - 28.9s]: amazing work you're doing organizing really all over the place.

[29.9s - 35.1s]: Shia Bastida is a 17 year old climate activist living in New York City.

[35.8s - 41.9s]: In 2018, she became the leader of her school's environmental club where she mobilized 600

[41.9s - 44.9s]: students in the first global climate strike.

[45.7s - 51.7s]: Since then, she has taken a citywide leadership role in organizing climate strikes and speaking

[51.7s - 54.4s]: out about climate justice issues in rallies.

[55.4s - 61.2s]: Bastida was born and raised in Mexico as part of the Atomi Toltek Indigenous Peoples.

[62.3s - 68.2s]: Currently, she is one of the lead organizers of Fridays for Future and sits in the Administration

[68.2s - 70.3s]: Committee of People's Climate Movement.

[70.9s - 76.5s]: Recently, she launched a youth activism training program to expand the climate justice movement.

[77.5s - 84.6s]: Shia is a member of Sunrise Movement, Extinction Rebellion and in 2018, she was invited

[84.6s - 90.7s]: to the 9th United Nations World Urban Forum to speak about Indigenous cosmology.

[91.4s - 96.8s]: Notably, she received the Spirit of the United Nations Award in 2018.

[97.7s - 101.0s]: Shia, it's so wonderful to have this opportunity to speak with you.

[101.4s - 102.7s]: Obviously, you and I have met.

[102.7s - 108.1s]: We've been together for a few days at the American Renewable Energy Day Conference in Snowmass

[108.1s - 108.5s]: Colorado.

[108.7s - 111.0s]: It's been an incredible gathering of folks.

[111.8s - 116.8s]: I am so excited to be able to share the story of what you're doing and most importantly,

[117.0s - 121.3s]: what our audience can do to get involved, regardless of where you're located.

[122.0s - 127.1s]: To dive right in, can you just share what's happening, what's coming up and what can we

[127.1s - 128.3s]: be engaging in?

[129.3s - 133.3s]: Right now, the youth movement, the climate strike movement, has really taken up.

[134.9s - 141.7s]: It's been a real catalyst for the future action that it's needed to address the climate

[141.7s - 142.0s]: crisis.

[143.3s - 146.8s]: Right now, we are organizing the September 20 climate strike.

[147.5s - 150.9s]: This is a different kind of strike because it's intergenerational.

[151.4s - 154.1s]: The past strikes that we've had had been youth led.

[154.1s - 158.3s]: On March 15, we got 1.6 million students marching with us worldwide.

[158.8s - 162.3s]: On May 24, we got 1.9 million students worldwide.

[162.6s - 167.1s]: And for September 20, we're calling for adults to join us because to solve the climate

[167.1s - 169.4s]: crisis, we need this movement to be collaborative.

[170.2s - 172.6s]: We ask youth, we cannot vote yet.

[173.6s - 181.1s]: So that's why we're relying on adults who can vote and represent the voice that we

[181.1s - 182.5s]: need to protect our future.

[183.5s - 189.6s]: And what we're doing is a lot of organizing, a lot of planning, a lot of outreach, and

[189.6s - 194.7s]: really getting the word out on why it's so important for us to address this issue right

[194.7s - 195.1s]: now.

[195.3s - 202.8s]: Because what we do in this next 10 and 0.5 years is really going to define the next 10,000

[202.8s - 203.1s]: years.

[203.5s - 210.1s]: Yeah, so this is this really underscores the sense of urgency that we really, we need

[210.1s - 211.7s]: to have around these issues, right?

[212.1s - 217.6s]: And I heard you earlier talk about the importance of our languaging around this and that the

[217.6s - 220.8s]: term climate change is really actually not an appropriate term anymore.

[220.8s - 220.9s]: Yes.

[221.8s - 227.4s]: So, up to recently, we've been using the term climate change to define what's happening

[227.4s - 228.3s]: in this world.

[228.7s - 232.4s]: But that term cannot encompass the catastrophe we're living in.

[232.8s - 238.0s]: We need to use terms of climate crisis, climate breakdown, climate emergency.

[238.0s - 243.2s]: Since the strike started, there has been over 600 governments who declared a climate

[243.2s - 243.8s]: emergency.

[244.5s - 252.5s]: And up for September 20th, which is going to be predating this September 23rd climate

[252.5s - 256.5s]: summit in the UN, we're asking all governments to declare climate emergency.

[258.9s - 263.9s]: And that is what we're bringing to the table, the sense of urgency.

[263.9s - 271.9s]: If we don't do something in really the next 18 months politically, we cannot ensure a

[271.9s - 272.7s]: livable future.

[272.9s - 278.3s]: In 10 years, I'm going to be 27 and I should be worrying about what I'm going to do after

[278.8s - 281.7s]: university and where I'm going to work, not where I have to live.

[282.0s - 282.8s]: Yeah, that's right.

[283.3s - 290.1s]: So I'm so struck as we discussed, she, you are the same age as my son Hunter.

[290.1s - 296.5s]: And he is also increasingly engaging in the ecological and environmental issues that

[296.5s - 297.2s]: face us.

[297.6s - 301.7s]: And I'm just, I'm so struck that you are putting so much of your time and energy into

[301.7s - 302.2s]: all of this.

[302.5s - 305.2s]: While also in a few weeks, you'll be back in high school.

[305.2s - 306.1s]: It's your senior year.

[306.5s - 307.9s]: You'll be applying to colleges.

[308.0s - 309.7s]: You'll be doing many of those things.

[310.1s - 316.7s]: My gosh, to take on this level of responsibility and really a sense of ownership around the

[316.7s - 318.7s]: imperative to impact the future.

[318.7s - 320.7s]: Where does that come from?

[321.1s - 324.2s]: What is it that planted that seed in you?

[325.1s - 329.8s]: So I am an auto me from Mexico, it's an indigenous community.

[330.7s - 335.2s]: And the indigenous philosophy is that we take care of the earth because the earth takes

[335.2s - 335.9s]: care of us.

[336.4s - 339.9s]: So we need to bring that sense of reciprocity into the movement.

[340.6s - 345.3s]: And we need to remember that we are on earth to take care of life, not to take over

[345.3s - 345.6s]: life.

[346.7s - 353.4s]: And something that really shifted my world around was that in 2015, my town suffered

[353.4s - 354.1s]: from flooding.

[354.9s - 357.8s]: And from then, we moved to New York City.

[359.1s - 362.9s]: And that is when I realized that the climate crisis follows you everywhere.

[363.2s - 366.9s]: There's no way to escape it because it's really affecting all of us.

[367.6s - 371.4s]: And it's the only issue that is affecting everyone everywhere.

[371.7s - 373.6s]: And the only thing we can do is face it.

[373.6s - 378.6s]: So that it doesn't affect some people more than others because that's the justice part

[378.6s - 380.0s]: of it that we're bringing to the table.

[380.4s - 381.1s]: Absolutely.

[381.8s - 388.1s]: So this event, September 20th, it sounds like this is going to be taking place in cities

[388.1s - 388.5s]: all over.

[388.7s - 389.4s]: Is that correct?

[389.6s - 389.8s]: Yes.

[390.1s - 394.1s]: So it's going to take place in over 130 countries.

[394.1s - 400.6s]: And there's over 6,000 people who have pledged to organize for September 20th.

[400.6s - 405.3s]: And in the United States alone, we have strikes in over 100 places.

[405.7s - 410.4s]: And if you visit strikewithas.org and you put your zip code in, you'll be directed

[410.4s - 411.5s]: to your nearest strike.

[411.9s - 417.9s]: If there's not a strike in a location that is comfortable for you, you can organize

[417.9s - 418.7s]: your own strike.

[419.0s - 424.6s]: And we have toolkits and resources for you to get permits and press and outreach.

[424.6s - 431.1s]: And we just really want this movement to expand all over the world nationally locally.

[431.7s - 438.9s]: And you shared also earlier that the strike on the 20th of September, that's not the final

[438.9s - 439.6s]: show.

[439.9s - 441.9s]: It's not the last draw by any stretch, is it?

[442.2s - 446.1s]: So we really want to emphasize that September 20th is not a goal.

[446.7s - 451.4s]: It's just a catalyst for future action and the engagement of humanity in the protection

[451.4s - 452.0s]: of Earth.

[452.0s - 457.6s]: Is the catalyst for the culmination of thousands of climate activists that won't stop fighting

[457.6s - 459.5s]: until the climate crisis is reversed?

[460.2s - 460.7s]: Absolutely.

[461.0s - 461.7s]: It's so important.

[464.4s - 469.2s]: So I have a question that I know a lot of our audience is going to relate to in different

[469.2s - 469.7s]: ways.

[470.6s - 475.0s]: And in other episodes, we've talked about the cultivation of health and well-being and

[475.0s - 479.1s]: maintaining balance in our own lives while we're also increasingly engaging in these

[479.1s - 481.0s]: incredibly important issues.

[482.0s - 489.1s]: And so what are some of the practices and the methods you're using to maintain that balance

[489.1s - 495.3s]: as you're putting so much of your energy into this mobilizing work while also working

[495.3s - 498.7s]: as a student and maintaining friendships and all that.

[498.8s - 500.1s]: What's your key for balance?

[500.8s - 507.1s]: So it's very important to keep your friendships flowing and your relationship with your family

[507.1s - 507.6s]: alive.

[508.4s - 515.0s]: And also it's very important to go back and be in contact with Earth and Mother Nature

[515.0s - 517.1s]: because that's when you remember what you're protecting.

[517.7s - 524.9s]: If you are in an office or studying for tests for hours, then you get disconnected from

[525.5s - 529.8s]: what we need to be in contact with.

[530.7s - 537.3s]: So one of the main things is really being in contact with nature, maintaining relationships

[537.3s - 537.9s]: open.

[539.6s - 550.0s]: You know, really ground yourself spiritually and keep this momentum going because I

[550.0s - 551.7s]: really bring it to everything you do.

[551.9s - 554.8s]: I believe that the climate crisis affects every aspect of our lives.

[555.4s - 559.4s]: So when I'm in school, my college essay is about the climate crisis.

[559.5s - 568.3s]: My research project in chemistry is about how a warming weather actually affects the oxygen

[568.3s - 568.8s]: in water.

[569.2s - 577.0s]: So I'm aware of this every day and my main purpose is to really communicate to others what's

[577.0s - 577.5s]: going on.

[578.2s - 582.6s]: And my passion is to help people and I believe that the climate crisis is affecting the most

[582.6s - 582.9s]: people.

[582.9s - 583.4s]: Absolutely.

[584.3s - 587.7s]: And I want to come back to that point in just a moment, but I can't help but share

[587.7s - 590.0s]: that a little bit older than you.

[590.1s - 591.9s]: As I mentioned, you're the same age as my son.

[592.4s - 597.7s]: I've been practicing and really attempting deliberately to deepen my own balance practice.

[597.9s - 603.5s]: And what I have found as a writer, as an activist, as somebody very engaged in recording

[603.5s - 608.8s]: episodes like this and so forth is that if I'm not deliberately going out and connecting

[608.8s - 614.2s]: with the woods and physically connecting with the soil, my cognitive performance declines,

[614.5s - 619.1s]: my energy declines, my mood and attitude actually gets negative.

[619.7s - 623.4s]: And sometimes I realize, holy smokes, I have so much work to do right now.

[624.0s - 627.5s]: The thing I have to do is unplug and go connect with nature.

[627.6s - 627.8s]: Yes.

[628.5s - 634.4s]: And one of the most important things as an activist is to really take care of yourself and

[634.4s - 634.9s]: eat.

[635.4s - 636.1s]: Don't forget to eat.

[636.3s - 637.4s]: Don't forget to sleep.

[638.3s - 644.0s]: And these are things that people who are in the movement don't tell you because we're

[644.0s - 646.2s]: so busy talking about solutions and actions.

[646.9s - 652.8s]: But in order to keep on going and in order to maintain the strength that we need, we really

[652.8s - 654.3s]: need to take care of each other.

[655.4s - 662.1s]: It's so beautiful and I really love that opportunity we have as individuals to understand

[662.1s - 667.7s]: and embrace and to practice the truth that stewardship regeneration sustainability really

[667.7s - 672.5s]: is an inside out gesture and it starts with how we're caring for ourselves and our immediate

[672.5s - 673.2s]: relationships.

[673.2s - 676.9s]: It's such a beautiful piece of wisdom for each of us to carry.

[677.8s - 680.9s]: Okay, so I have to ask, you mentioned chemistry.

[681.5s - 685.9s]: What are you thinking about in terms of what you want to study and where you think you'll

[685.9s - 687.4s]: be heading on the personal path?

[687.9s - 697.7s]: So I wanted to study biochemistry a while ago, but now I realize that we as students, we

[697.7s - 702.5s]: are messengers of the X-16 science and the climate crisis has been solved.

[702.7s - 704.4s]: We just need to implement those solutions.

[705.0s - 710.1s]: So now I'm going into environmental studies, international relations and political science

[710.7s - 716.4s]: because I believe that now we just need to bring all of this together and really keep

[716.4s - 721.6s]: communicating it to people and really realize that this is a global issue that requires

[721.6s - 722.7s]: global solutions.

[723.1s - 723.6s]: Absolutely.

[723.9s - 727.6s]: You know, this is something so many of us in the Y and Earth community are really familiar

[727.6s - 729.3s]: with that by and large.

[729.3s - 733.3s]: We are not facing mere technical challenges.

[733.4s - 737.6s]: In fact, we have a lot of the solutions as you say and that ultimately this is a question

[737.6s - 743.2s]: of culture and this is a question of what we're mobilizing as a society and why, right?

[743.3s - 745.7s]: The fundamental why, which is why we call it Y and Earth.

[746.7s - 753.3s]: And you know, we need to change this culture of consumerism, of complacency.

[753.8s - 757.7s]: In order to change that culture, we need to change the narrative.

[758.7s - 763.6s]: And in order to change the narrative, we need to communicate personal stories of people

[763.6s - 766.7s]: who are going through hard times in real time.

[767.9s - 770.2s]: So we are really into this movement.

[770.2s - 778.5s]: And we're really bringing forward personal stories and personal solutions to make it personal

[778.5s - 779.9s]: because the environment is personal.

[780.2s - 780.5s]: Absolutely.

[781.1s - 785.3s]: And on that note, with your personal story, you and your team recently put together

[785.3s - 791.4s]: a beautiful video that we'll be sharing on our Y on Earth.org blog page where you'll

[791.4s - 794.2s]: see a handful of other videos from some of our other ambassadors.

[795.0s - 799.9s]: And she, to make it official, I'm so happy to welcome you as our newest ambassador

[799.9s - 801.2s]: to the Y and Earth community.

[801.6s - 805.6s]: And it's a real honor to be able to share your story and what you're doing with our network.

[806.1s - 812.5s]: And the fundamental hope and imperative here folks is that each of us is mobilizing around

[812.5s - 813.0s]: these efforts.

[813.6s - 820.5s]: And I want to say in addition to engaging with the protest movement in your area on September

[821.3s - 826.9s]: 20th, also, please consider supporting financially the work that she is doing.

[826.9s - 830.8s]: And if folks want to support financially, how do they connect with you to do that?

[830.9s - 835.3s]: The best way to connect is to go to our website, start with us.

[835.5s - 841.5s]: And we have a coalition of seven youth groups, including Extension Rebellion Youth, Sunrise

[841.5s - 847.3s]: Movement, Future Coalition, Prideous for Future, US Youth Climate Strike, Earth Guardians,

[847.9s - 848.7s]: and Earth套 pricing.

[849.3s - 851.1s]: Any of these organizations take money.

[851.1s - 861.4s]: And right now we're putting together a fund where we can direct all of our donors and

[861.4s - 863.7s]: we can take money accordingly.

[864.0s - 864.4s]: Oh, beautiful.

[864.7s - 869.6s]: Okay, so it's kind of like a central shared fundraising resource that you guys are then

[869.6s - 871.5s]: allocating out of depending on what's happening.

[871.7s - 874.2s]: Okay, that's really, really beautiful to know you're doing that.

[875.2s - 879.1s]: Well I have to say we've got off camera, we've got mom.

[879.1s - 880.9s]: Your mom is here with us, Geraldine.

[881.6s - 889.4s]: And as a parent, my heart is just glowing, knowing that she is doing this incredible work

[889.4s - 896.4s]: in that she and other students like her are the force that is creating the future we want

[896.4s - 897.8s]: for our kids and our grandkids.

[898.3s - 902.7s]: And Geraldine knows, hoping you might come join us on camera here and just share a little

[902.7s - 909.1s]: with us for you as mom, how does this feel that this is all happening?

[910.1s - 920.3s]: Well for me it's a continuation of the energy that dad and mom have been channeling for

[920.3s - 921.1s]: a long time.

[922.7s - 932.4s]: We were also activists that were mobilizing Mindajee in Mexico and myself.

[932.4s - 938.8s]: In the south of Chile, we were trying to make people understand that we didn't need

[938.8s - 944.6s]: to dam the most sacred river of the Mapucha peoples in seven places.

[945.2s - 950.6s]: That energy was really not necessary if we were all conscious of how we were consuming

[951.6s - 954.6s]: the electricity in our homes and in the industry.

[955.6s - 964.6s]: And that required a lot of frontline presence together with our Mapuchesisters and brothers.

[965.5s - 975.2s]: But also being there in city halls or the equivalent in Chile and calling for press conferences

[975.2s - 976.6s]: for a long time.

[977.8s - 990.4s]: And ever since when I moved to Mexico we came together with your father, we also continued

[990.4s - 1001.5s]: in this path through keeping a space in the newspaper nationally where we would especially

[1001.5s - 1004.0s]: be writing for this newspaper.

[1005.6s - 1013.1s]: We became professors at university so we've always been channeling a philosophy that is about

[1013.1s - 1018.5s]: the caring of our life which is what we have inherited to you.

[1019.3s - 1024.5s]: And I think that you're doing it in such a balanced way, you know, communicating so we

[1024.5s - 1029.6s]: feel really proud of you and we were here to support you in every level.

[1029.6s - 1031.9s]: Yeah, absolutely beautiful.

[1032.7s - 1036.1s]: And as a professor what do you teach?

[1036.6s - 1038.1s]: So it's ethno ecology.

[1038.2s - 1039.1s]: Ethno ecology, cool.

[1039.2s - 1042.9s]: And maybe for some of our audience you might not be familiar with that.

[1042.9s - 1047.1s]: Ethno speaks about indigenous peoples, right?

[1048.0s - 1054.4s]: And so ethno ecology is the interdiscipline, it's a combination of disciplines where you

[1054.4s - 1059.9s]: are able to understand together with an indigenous community how is it that their custom

[1059.9s - 1069.0s]: vision and their value system and their loss of origin and their original stories or creation

[1069.0s - 1076.1s]: stories drive how they interact with Mother Earth, how they understand and build knowledge

[1076.1s - 1084.5s]: around Mother Earth and her cycles and how it will determine what they do when they do

[1084.5s - 1088.7s]: it throughout the year cycle and how they will be reading the signs that nature gives

[1088.7s - 1089.2s]: them.

[1089.4s - 1092.9s]: So to do this or that or to plant this or that.

[1095.1s - 1103.8s]: So it's being beautiful, you know, it's allowed me to understand also the original calendars

[1103.8s - 1110.5s]: of Mesoamerica meaning the Maya calendar, the otomi total calendars of your dad's people

[1110.5s - 1114.2s]: and also the Mishikaastic calendar.

[1114.5s - 1114.6s]: Right.

[1115.4s - 1117.1s]: Some of the most sophisticated in the world.

[1117.2s - 1121.4s]: Yeah, yeah, yeah, they are and it's fascinating.

[1122.7s - 1123.3s]: It's absolutely wonderful.

[1123.6s - 1128.4s]: The mention of cycles reminds me last night.

[1128.4s - 1137.8s]: There was some discussion around the predominant Judeo-Christian and Abrahamic creation stories

[1137.8s - 1145.5s]: and stories and mythologies around time as it continues in this linear notion versus an

[1145.5s - 1150.5s]: understanding that it's cyclical, which all of us, regardless of where we come from on

[1150.5s - 1156.1s]: the planet, we are all of indigenous heritage and all of our peoples, if we go far enough

[1156.1s - 1159.3s]: back in time, had a cyclical understanding of the reality.

[1159.3s - 1163.3s]: That's how things work here with the moon, the solar cycles, the seasonal cycles, the

[1163.3s - 1164.5s]: water cycles, etc.

[1164.9s - 1165.3s]: That's right.

[1165.5s - 1167.5s]: And I'm so struck.

[1167.7s - 1174.2s]: I love, first of all, I have to share that my personal attunement to lunar cycles, to

[1174.2s - 1179.1s]: solar cycles, to seasonal cycles actually makes me happier and more balanced as an individual.

[1179.3s - 1179.5s]: Yeah.

[1179.5s - 1180.9s]: I know that from experience.

[1181.0s - 1181.2s]: Yeah.

[1181.5s - 1186.0s]: And I'm curious from your perspective with a different cultural context, what do you think

[1186.0s - 1190.3s]: that this means in terms of what we're doing as a global society?

[1191.0s - 1198.5s]: So right now we are on a lot of linear cycles, not only in terms of time, but also in terms

[1198.5s - 1201.7s]: of money and the economy.

[1202.2s - 1207.4s]: So what we want is more production, more money, more growth.

[1208.2s - 1211.2s]: And in control of all growth is another type of cancer.

[1211.6s - 1214.3s]: And that system that we're in right now is unhealthy.

[1215.0s - 1216.7s]: So we need to go back to cycles.

[1217.1s - 1221.4s]: And it doesn't mean it's here, but it's a spiral that goes up.

[1222.0s - 1223.3s]: And we trust sand with it.

[1223.4s - 1232.2s]: And we need to go, as you said, back to recognizing the cycles to harvest, to plant cycles of

[1232.2s - 1234.2s]: calendar, cycles of consumption.

[1235.1s - 1236.7s]: We're not telling you don't need need.

[1236.9s - 1239.2s]: We're telling you need when there's a special occasion.

[1239.8s - 1246.0s]: So we need to bring back that consciousness of really connecting with the cycles of the

[1246.0s - 1246.3s]: earth.

[1246.6s - 1253.4s]: And when you disrespect, when you disrespect the cycles, you're disrespecting indigenous

[1253.4s - 1255.6s]: cosmology and you're disrespecting the earth itself.

[1256.0s - 1256.1s]: Yeah.

[1256.7s - 1262.7s]: And for those of us who believe in a creator, it's a disrespect of our creator, right?

[1263.5s - 1263.6s]: Absolutely.

[1264.0s - 1264.0s]: 

[1264.5s - 1270.8s]: So I have to also ask, as a parent, one of the things we get to do as parents is name

[1270.8s - 1271.4s]: our children.

[1272.0s - 1272.2s]: Yeah.

[1272.2s - 1280.4s]: And I know that she has a beautiful name with a lot of meaning layered into it.

[1280.5s - 1282.7s]: And I was wondering if you might share that with us.

[1283.3s - 1283.5s]: Yeah.

[1283.7s - 1292.1s]: So when she was still in my womb, we were thinking with dad what was your name going to be.

[1292.8s - 1294.3s]: And she came a lot.

[1294.6s - 1297.4s]: So she means soft rain, drizzling rain.
